questions.text: Most common corneal dystrophy is
questions.solution:
Corneal map-dot-fingerprint dystrophy is by far the most common type of corneal dystrophy.

Map-dot-fingerprint dystrophy is also known as epithelial basement membrane dystrophy, anterior basement membrane dystrophy, and Cogan microcystic epithelial dystrophy.

questions.text: Fundus changes in pathological myopia includes all except
questions.solution:
Pseudopapillitis is a feature of hypermetropia.

Fundus changes in myopia:

  • Large and pale optic disc
  • Temporal myopic crescent and peripapillary crescent
  • Foster fuch’s spots at the macula (Subretinal neovascularisation and choroidal haemorrhage)
  • Cystoid degeneration and Lattice degeneration
  • Tigroid or tessellated appearance of fundus
  • Lacquer cracks - Linear breaks in Bruch's membrane
  • Posterior staphyloma
  • Vitreous – liquefaction, opacities, posterior vitreous detachment – Weiss reflex

questions.text: Microaneurysms which are the earliest manifestation of diabetic retinopathy most frequently develop in which layer
questions.solution:
Microaneurysms are localized outpouchings, mainly saccular, of the capillary wall that may form either by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent, or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.

  • Most develop in the inner capillary plexus (inner nuclear layer), frequently adjacent to areas of capillary non-perfusion.
  • Loss of pericytes may also lead to endothelial cell proliferation with the formation of ‘cellular’ microaneurysms.
  • Microaneurysms may leak plasma constituents into the retina as a result of breakdown in the blood–retinal barrier, or may thrombose.
  • They tend to be the earliest sign of DR.

questions.text: You would identify the instrument shown in the image below as:
questions.solution:
The image shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique) which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens.

Option A: Nagel’s anomaloscope is used to test color vision.

Option C: Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

questions.text: Corneal transparency is maintained by all of the following factors, except _______.
questions.solution:
Corneal transparency is maintained by all of the given factors except irregularity of stromal collagen fibrils. The regularity of stromal collagen fibrils, which are arranged as a lattice, contributes to the transparency of the cornea. 

Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are:

  • Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
  • Avascularity of the cornea
  • Endothelial pumps such as Na+/K+ ATPase pump, bicarbonate-dependent ATPase, Na+/H+ pump.
  • Evaporation from the corneal surface.
  • Normal intraocular pressure.
  • Swelling pressure of the stroma.
  • Corneal crystallins: water-soluble proteins of keratocytes
  • Barrier function of epithelium and endothelium

questions.text: Shaffer’s sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Shaffer’s sign or tobacco dusting refers to the presence of pigment cells in the anterior vitreous. It is seen in retinal detachment (RD), especially rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

The image shows tobacco dust appearance (Shaffer's sign) in the anterior vitreous.

In rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. 

Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous hemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Treatment of rhegmatogenous RD includes:

  • Prophylactic laser barrage
  • Scleral buckling
  • Pneumatic retinopexy
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: Phacomorphic glaucoma is an example of
questions.solution:
Phacomorphic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma precipitated by an intumescent cataractous lens.

The lens becomes intumescent, either by the rapid development of cataractous changes or after a traumatic rupture of its capsule.

The swollen lens obliterates the drainage angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea.

Note:

  • Phacolytic glaucoma is a secondary open-angle glaucoma occurring in association with a hypermature cataract. Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule into the aqueous humour leading to trabecular obstruction; macrophages containing lens proteins may also contribute.
  • Phacogenic (previously phacoanaphylactic) uveitis, an autoimmune granulomatous reaction to exposed lens proteins occurring with a compromised lens capsule.

questions.text: Chrysiasis is due to deposition of
questions.solution:
Chrysiasis is the deposition of gold in living tissue, and typically occurs only after prolonged administration.

Virtually all patients who have received a total dose of gold compound exceeding 1500 mg develop corneal deposits, characterized by dust-like or glittering purple granules scattered throughout the epithelium and stroma, concentrated in the deep layers and the periphery.

questions.text: Arlt’s line is seen in
questions.solution:
Arlt’s line is a conjunctival sign seen in trachoma.

It is a characteristic white conjunctival scar usually formed at the junction between the lower third and upper two-third of the superior tarsus.

Clinical signs in trachoma:

Corneal signs of trachoma include:

  • Superficial keratitis
  • Herbert’s follicles – Limbal area
  • Pannus – superior limbus
  • Corneal ulcer
  • Herberts pits – Limbal area
  • Corneal opacity

Conjunctival signs of trachoma include:

  • Congestion – On upper tarsal, fornix
  • Follicles (Containing Leber cells on histopathology) – On upper tarsal, fornix
  • Papillary hyperplasia
  • Arlt’s line – Linear scarring in sulcus subtarsalis
  • Concretions – Inspissated mucus, dead epithelial cells in Glands of Henle

questions.text: “a” wave in ERG corresponds to the activity of
questions.solution:
"a" wave in ERG corresponds to activity of rods and cones.

The electroretinogram (ERG) is a diagnostic test that measures the electrical activity generated by neural and non-neuronal cells in the retina in response to a light stimulus.

The normal ERG is predominantly biphasic:

  • a-wave: Initial corneal-negative deflection, derived from the cones and rods of the outer photoreceptor layers
  • b-wave: Corneal-positive deflection; derived from the inner retina, predominantly Muller and bipolar cells
  • c-wave: Derived from the retinal pigment epithelium and photoreceptors

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the newborn eye?

choices.text: A refractive error of -2D is present

questions.solution:
The newborn eye is usually hypermetropic by +2 to +3 D.

Features of the eye in a newborn:

  • The anteroposterior diameter of the eyeball is about 70% of the adult size- 16.5 mm. Adult size is attained by 7–8 years of age.
  • The corneal diameter is approximately 10 mm. Adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age.
  • The anterior chamber has a narrow-angle and is shallow.
  • The pupil is small and does not dilate completely.
  • The lens has a spherical shape at birth and has infantile nucleus.
  • The retina is fully differentiated, except for the macular area. The differentiation of macula occurs 4–6 months after birth.
  • The myelination of optic nerve fibers reaches upto the lamina cribrosa.
  • The newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2 to +3 D.
  • The orbit has more divergence (50°) as compared to adult (45°).
  • The lacrimal gland is underdeveloped and tears are not secreted.

questions.text: All of the following cause Apollo conjunctivitis except
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause a follicular conjunctivitis, particularly in primary infection; this is usually unilateral and there are often associated skin vesicles.

Apollo conjunctivitis is acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis caused by (mnemonic PACE):

  • Picornavirus
  • Adenovirus 11
  • Coxsackie A-24 virus
  • Enterovirus 70

It has a rapid onset, and resolves within 1–2 weeks. Conjunctival haemorrhage is generally marked.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about lens is

choices.text: Anterior surface is more convex than the posterior surface
Lens has highest protein concentration among all body tissues
Posterior pole is the thinnest region of capsule
Lens grows in size continuously throughout life

questions.solution:
The radius of curvature of the anterior surface of the lens is 10 mm and of the posterior surface is 6 mm i.e. posterior surface is more convex.

Option b: The lens is composed of 64% water, 35% protein, and 1% lipid, carbohydrate and trace elements.

The protein concentration in the lens is actually the highest amongst body tissues.

The main types of proteins are alpha (31%), beta (55%) and gamma (2%) crystallins, and insoluble albuminoids (12%).

Option c: Lens capsule is thicker over the anterior surface than posterior surface. It is thickest at the pre-equator regions and thinnest at the posterior pole.

Option d: The lens grows in size continuously throughout life, and in this respect it is unique among the organs of the body.

questions.text: Identify the disorder associated with the type of cataract show in below given image
questions.solution:
Image shows shield-like dense anterior subcapsular plaque that wrinkles the anterior capsule which is characteristic of cataract seen in atopic dermatitis.

Option a: Classic diabetic cataract, which is actually rare, consists of snowflake cortical opacities occurring in the young diabetic; it may mature within a few days or resolve spontaneously.

Age-related cataract occurs earlier in diabetes mellitus.

Nuclear opacities are common and tend to progress rapidly.

Option b: About 90% of patients with myotonic dystrophy develop fine iridescent cortical opacities in the third decade, sometimes resembling Christmas tree cataract.

Option d: Rosette cataract is seen in case of blunt trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Ectopia lentis
questions.solution:
Myasthenia gravis is not a cause of Ectopia lentis. Hyperlysinaemia, Marfan’s syndrome, sulfite oxidase deficiency are all causes of Ectopia lentis.

Ectopia lentis refers to a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position.

Causes:

Acquired

  • Trauma
  • Pseudoexfoliation
  • Inflammation, e.g. chronic cyclitis, syphilis
  • Hypermature cataract
  • Large eye, e.g. high myopia, buphthalmos
  • Anterior uveal tumours

Congenital:

  • Familial Ectopia lentis – Autosomal dominant, superotemporal displacement.
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae - AR inheritance, displacement of the pupil and the lens in opposite directions
  • Marfan syndrome – Superotemporal displacement
  • Weil-Marchesani syndrome – Forward subluxation, spherophakia
  • Homocytinuria - Inferonasal displacement

Other systemic conditions associated with ectopia lentis include

  • Sulfite oxidase deficiency - Ectopia lentis is universal
  • Stickler syndrome - Retinal detachment is the most common ocular manifestation
  • Ehlers–Danlos syndrome
  • Hyperlysinaemia

questions.text: In which surgery would you use the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: The image shows a Ziegler knife, which is used to open the lens capsule and aspirate the lens material in congenital cataract surgeries.

questions.text: Haab’s striae is due to tears in:
questions.solution:
Haab's striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet membrane seen in case of buphthalmos (congenital glaucoma). These occur because Descemet’s membrane is less elastic than corneal stroma. It is seen as double 'tram-track' lines concentric to the limbus.

Tears are:

  • Usually peripheral
  • Concentric with the limbus
  • Appear as lines with double contour

Note: Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

questions.text: Maximum resistance to aqueous outflow is at
questions.solution:
Juxtacanalicular/cribriform meshwork offers maximum resistance to aqueous outflow.

Aqueous outflow:

  • Trabecular/conventional outflow – Main outlet draining 90% of aqueous via trabeculum into the Schlemm canal and then the episcleral veins.
  • Uveoscleral outflow – Drains around 10% of aqueous via ciliary body into the suprachoroidal space, and is drained by the venous circulation in the ciliary body, choroid and sclera.

Trabecular meshwork: It has 3 components

  • The uveal meshwork:
    • Innermost portion
    • Consists of cord-like endothelial cell-covered strands arising from the iris and ciliary body stroma
    • Intertrabecular spaces are relatively large and offer little resistance to the passage of aqueous.
  • The corneoscleral meshwork:
    • Lies external to the uveal meshwork
    • Thickest portion of the trabeculum
    • Composed of layers of connective tissue strands with overlying endothelial-like cells
    • Intertrabecular spaces are smaller than those of the uveal meshwork, conferring greater resistance to flow.
  • The juxtacanalicular (cribriform) meshwork:
    • Outer part of the trabeculum
    • Consists of cells embedded in a dense extracellular matrix with narrow intercellular spaces
    • Offers the major proportion of normal resistance to aqueous outflow.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with complaints of pain, photophobia, and redness in the eye following injury by vegetative matter. On examination, appearance is as shown in the below-given image. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Signs are more pronounced than symptoms
Wessely’s immune ring is a feature
It can occur in immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
This patient with history of ocular injury due to vegetative matter with ocular pain, redness, and the image depicting a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and a hypopyon is likely to have a fungal corneal ulcer. In this condition, the hypopyon is not sterile. 

Fungal or mycotic keratitis is seen in tropical countries, rural areas, and in individuals who are immunocompromised. It occurs due to inoculation with Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida species. It is generally seen after ocular injury with vegetable matter. 

The signs of a fungal corneal ulcer are generally more pronounced than the symptoms. Signs include: 

  • Dry slough with feathery borders
  • Thick, immobile, hypopyon that occurs due to direct invasion of anterior chamber by fungal hyphae in thick exudates
  • Wesseley's immune ring due to deposition of immune complexes and inflammatory cells around the ulcer
  • Satellite lesions
  • Ciliary and conjunctival congestion (symptoms of pain, watering, and photophobia are less severe than in cases of bacterial corneal ulcers)

Fungal corneal ulcers are treated topically with natamycin, voriconazole, nystatin, or amphotericin B drops. If the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated, or if there is endophthalmitis, then systemic antifungals need to be provided. Examples include oral ketoconazole or voriconazole. Surgical management is indicated if the ulcer progresses despite medical therapy.

questions.text: Wedl cells are described in association with
questions.solution:
Wedl cells are associated with cataract especially posterior subcapsular cataract.

Histopathologically, PSC is associated with posterior migration of the lens epithelial cells from the lens equator to the axis on the inner surface of the posterior capsule. During their migration to or after their arrival at the posterior axis, the cells undergo aberrant enlargement. These swollen cells are called Wedl or bladder cells.

questions.text: 90 day glaucoma is seen in:
questions.solution:
90 day glaucoma is seen in central retinal vein occlusion because it typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event.

Central retinal vein occlusions (CRVO) typically affect elderly patients in the sixth or seventh decade of life. Some of the risk factors include :

  • Age >50 years
  • Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma
  • Oral contraceptive pills and hormone replacement therapy
  • Smoking

There are two variants - non-ischemic and ischemic.

Non-ischemic CRVO is the most common clinical variety and presents with unilateral mild to moderate blurring of vision of sudden onset. Relative apparent pupillary defect (RAPD) is absent or very mild. Fundoscopy reveals mild venous congestion and tortuosity, with superficial peripheral flame-shaped hemorrhages.

Ischemic CRVO refers to acute complete occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is characterized by marked sudden visual loss and RAPD is present. Fundoscopy shows massively engorged, congested and tortuous retinal veins. Retinal hemorrhages are massive giving a splashed tomato appearance. Cotton wool spots are numerous and the optic disc shows edema and hyperemia. In the late stages, neovascularization may be seen at the disc or in the periphery.


Complications : 

  • Rubeosis iridis, i.e. neovascularisation of iris and neovascular glaucoma occur in about 20% of cases within 3 months (so also called 90 days glaucoma)
  • Vitreous hemorrhage and proliferative retinopathy

Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments can you use to measure corneal thickness?
questions.solution:
The pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options A and D: A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.

Option C: Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under a very high magnification (100 times greater than slit lamp biomicroscopy). Endothelium can be analyzed for cellular size, shape, density, and distribution. The healthy endothelial cell is a regular hexagon, and the normal cell density in a young adult is about 3000 cells/mm2.

questions.text: Treatment of malignant glaucoma is
questions.solution:
All are used in management of malignant glaucoma.

Malignant glaucoma:

  • It can be seen after any intraocular surgery.
  • Forward flow of aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against lens/IOL/Anterior hyaloid of vitreous. Hence aqueous starts collecting in vitreous cavity.

Clinical features:

  • Persistent Flat AC
  • Negative seidel’s test
  • Raised IOP

Treatment

  • Atropine:
    • Malignant glaucoma also called Inverse glaucoma since atropine is used.
    • It dilates the ciliary ring and increase the distance between the ciliary processes and the equator of the lens, thereby tightening the zonule and pulling the lens posteriorly into its normal position.
  • Intravenous mannitol may be used if mydriatics are ineffective, in order to shrink the vitreous gel and allow the lens to move posteriorly.
  • Nd: YAG laser hyaloidotomy - making opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: Drowsiness is side effect of which of the following agents used in the treatment of glaucoma
questions.solution:
Apraclonidine is a selective alpha 2 agonist used in treatment of glaucoma.

Drowsiness, headache and fatigue are its systemic side effects.

Allergies and fluctuations in visual acuity are the ocular side effects.

questions.text: Volume of vitreous
questions.solution:
The vitreous is a transparent extracellular gel consisting of collagen, soluble proteins, hyaluronic acid and water.

Its total volume is approximately 4.0 ml.

questions.text: Skin depigmentation, bilateral uveitis, poliosis, and tinnitus are features of
questions.solution:
Uveitis associated with vitiligo, poliosis, tinnitus and vertigo suggest diagnosis of Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome.

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome:

  • Idiopathic multisystem autoimmune disease featuring inflammation of melanocyte-containing tissues such as the uvea, ear and meninges.
  • Associated with HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4
  • Subdivided into
    • Vogt–Koyanagi disease - characterized mainly by skin changes and anterior uveitis
    • Harada disease - neurological features and exudative retinal detachments predominate

Clinical features:

Prodromal phase:

  • Neurological - meningitis and rarely encephalopathy with cranial nerve paresis and other focal lesions
  • Auditory manifestations (tinnitus, vertigo and deafness)
  • Cranial nerve palsies and optic neuritis may occur

Acute uveitic phase:

  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules – small, discrete, yellow white lesions usually at the periphery formed due to accumulation of epitheloid cells and lymphocytes along with proliferation of retinal pigment epithelium between Bruchs membrane and RPE
  • Vitritis
  • Papillitis
  • Exudative retinal detachments

Convalescent phase:

  • Localized alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo
  • Depigmented fundus appearance - ‘sunset glow’ fundus
  • Depigmented limbal lesions - Sugiura sign in pigmented, especially Japanese, patients

Images below show Dalen Fuch's nodules and sunset glow fundus.

questions.text: Which of the following is currently used for the prophylaxis of non infectious uveitis in LUMINATE programme?
questions.solution:
The LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) clinical development program was initiated in 2007 to assess the safety and efficacy of voclosporin for the treatment, maintenance, and control of all forms of noninfectious uveitis.

Currently, available therapies are burdened with toxicities and/or lack definitive evidence of efficacy.

Voclosporin, a rationally designed novel calcineurin inhibitor, exhibits a favourable safety profile, a strong correlation between pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic response, and a wide therapeutic window. 

If LUMINATE is successful, voclosporin will become the first Food and Drug Administration-approved corticosteroid-sparing agent for this condition.

questions.text: Amsler sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Amsler sign refers to fine filiform hemorrhage from the opposite angle on opening anterior chamber during cataract surgery.

It is seen in case of Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis.

  • As the name suggests it is chronic low-grade non-granulomatous cyclitis associated with heterochromia of iris.
  • Fine stellate keratic precipitates at the back of cornea differentiate it from congenital heterochromia.

Other features:

  • Diffuse stromal iris atrophy
  • Faint aqueous flare
  • Absence of posterior Synechiae
  • Rubeosis iridis
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract
  • Glaucoma – typically occurs late

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Treatment of larger defects requires skin grafts.
Treacher Collins syndrome is associated with coloboma of eyelid.
It usually occurs near the temporal side

questions.solution:
The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. Option D is the false statement as it usually occurs near the nasal side and not the temporal side.

Coloboma of the eyelid is a partial or full-thickness eyelid defect. It more frequently involves the upper lid (Option B) than the lower lid and usually occurs on the nasal side. It occurs when eyelid development is incomplete, due to failure of migration of lid ectoderm to fuse with the lid folds.

Upper-lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and inner thirds and have a relatively strong association with cryptophthalmos, facial abnormalities, and Goldenhar syndrome. (Cryptophthalmos is a congenital anomaly in which the eyelids are absent, replaced by a continuous layer of skin). Lower lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and outer thirds and are frequently associated with systemic conditions. 

Treacher Collins syndrome is characterized by malformations in the derivatives of first and second branchial arches, primarily mandibular and ear anomalies. Lower eyelid coloboma (Option C) is a feature of this syndrome along with slanted palpebral apertures, cataracts, microphthalmos, and lacrimal atresia. 

Small defects can be managed by primary closure, while large defects require skin grafts (Option A) and rotation flaps.

questions.text: WHO criteria for blindness is visual acuity less than
questions.solution: According to the WHO, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.

questions.text: Angioid streaks in fundus are seen in case of
questions.solution:
Angioid streaks are found in case of sickle cell disease.

Angioid streaks are crack-like dehiscences in brittle thickened and calcified Bruch membrane, associated with atrophy of the overlying RPE.

Causes:

  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE)
  • Ehlers–Danlos syndrome
  • Paget disease
  • Haemoglobinopathies - Sickle-cell trait and disease and thalassaemias

questions.text: The lesion in the below-given image is a side effect of:
questions.solution:
Image shows bull’s eye macular lesion, characterized by a foveolar island of pigment surrounded by a depigmented zone of RPE atrophy, which is itself encircled by a hyperpigmented ring.

It is a side effect of Chloroquine.

Other causes are:

  • Cone dystrophy
  • Cone-rod dystrophy
  • Ceroid lipofuscinosis
  • Stargardt's and fundus flavimaculatus
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy
  • Parafoveal atrophy of RPE secondary to AMD
  • Central areolar choroidal dystrophy
  • Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy
  • Juvenile Batten's disease
  • Fucosidosis
  • Clofazimine maculopathy

questions.text: True statement about fovea is
questions.solution:
The fovea

  • Depression in the retinal surface at the centre of the macula with a diameter of 1.5 mm.
  • It has lowest threshold for light and is responsible for maximum visual acuity.
  • It is the most sensitive part of retina.

Anatomy of retina:

It is divided by retinal equator (Imaginary line lying in line with the exit of 4 vena verticose) into peripheral retina and posterior pole.

Posterior pole:

Optic disc:

  • Circular area of 1.5mm diameter
  • Depression in centre – physiological cup
  • Central retinal artery and vein emerge through the centre of this cup

Macula lutea

Also called yellow spot - yellow xanthophylls carotenoid pigments lutein and zeaxanthin in far higher concentration than the peripheral retina

  • The fovea
    • Depression in the retinal surface at the centre of the macula with a diameter of 1.5 mm.
    • It has lowest threshold for light and is responsible for maximum visual acuity.
    • It is the most sensitive part of retina.
  • The foveola forms the central floor of the fovea and has a diameter of 0.35 mm. It is the thinnest part of the retina and is devoid of ganglion cells, consisting only of a high density of cone photoreceptors and their nuclei, together with Müller cells.
  • The umbo is a depression in the very centre of the foveola which corresponds to the foveolar light reflex, loss of which may be an early sign of damage.
  • The foveal avascular zone - a central area containing no blood vessels but surrounded by a continuous network of capillaries.

questions.text: Mizuo phenomenon is seen in
questions.solution:
Mizuo phenomenon is seen in case of Oguchi’s disease (AR).

The fundus has an unusual golden yellow colour in the light-adapted state, which becomes normal after prolonged dark adaptation (Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon).

Rod function is absent after 30 minutes of dark adaptation but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation.

Option a: Morning glory syndrome:

  • Variant of coloboma of optic disc
  • Unilateral
  • More common in females
  • PAX6 gene mutation
  • Disc: Enlarged, orange or pink color disc with funnel-shaped excavation at the centre covered by a white tuft of glial tissue which represents persistent hyaloid vascular remnants with surrounding area of peripapillary chorioretinal pigmentary changes.

Option b: Optic disc hypoplasia has characteristic double ring sign.

questions.text: Equal and simultaneous innervation to a pair of yoke muscles is explained by __________
questions.solution:
Equal and simultaneous innervation to a pair of yoke muscles is explained by the Hering's law of equal innervation.

 Hering's law of equal innervation

Whenever an impulse for the performance of an eye movement is sent out, corresponding yoke muscles of each eye receive equal innervations to contract or to relax. This is the law of equal innervations proposed by Hering.

  • Eg: During levoversion, the right medial rectus and left lateral rectus receives an equal and simultaneous flow of innervations.

Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation (Option A):

It states that during the initiation of an eye movement, increased innervation to an extraocular muscle is accompanied by simultaneous inhibition (a reciprocal decrease in innervation) of the direct antagonist of the contracting muscle of the same eye.

  • Eg: During levoversion, An increased innervational flow to the right medial and left lateral rectus, accompanied by decreased flow of innervations to right lateral rectus and left medial rectus  

Donders' law (Option C):

It states that for anyone gaze direction, the eye always assumes the same unique orientation in 3 dimensions. The orientation is always the same irrespective of where the eye came from. 

  • For example, the orientation of the eye when looking up and right is the same when the eye reached this position by first rotating right and then up or first up and then right.

Listing's Law (Option D):

It is the specific realization of the more general 'Donders' law', which states that for any one gaze direction the eye's 3D spatial orientation is unique and independent of how the eye reached that gaze direction (previous gaze directions / eye orientations / temporal movements).

questions.text: Length of intraocular part of the optic nerve
questions.solution:
Intraocular part of optic nerve is approximately 1mm in length.

The optic nerve consists of approximately 1.2 million axons that arise from the retinal ganglion cells and has four parts: 

  • Intraocular portion (1 mm), i.e. the optic nerve head visible as the optic disc on fundus examination
  • Intra-orbital portion (25-30 mm)
  • Intracanalicular portion (5-9 mm)
  • Intracranial portion (10-16 mm) - goes up to the optic chiasma

questions.text: Angle represented in below given image is
questions.solution:
Image represents angle kappa between visual axis and pupillary axis.

Clinically this is the angle usually measured. 

It is positive in pseudo-exotropria and negative in pseudo-esotropia.

Axes of the eye:

  • Optic axis – Line passing through the centre of cornea, centre of lens and meets retina on nasal side of fovea.
  • Visual axis – Line passing through fixation point, nodal point and fovea.
  • Fixation axis – Line passing through fixation point and centre of rotation.
  • Pupillary line – Line perpendicular to the cornea at the point coinciding to the centre of pupil.

Angles:

  • Angle alpha: Angle between visual axis and optic axis at the nodal point.

Mnemonic: VOA (Voice Of America) Visual axis, Optic axis and Alpha angle

  • Angle gamma: Angle between Fixation axis and optic axis at the centre of rotation of eyeball. 

Mnemonic: FOG – Fixation axis, Optic axis, Gamma angle

  • Angle kappa: Angle between pupillary line and visual axis at cornea.

Mnemonic: PVK (Pak V/S Kashmir) – Pupillary line, Visual axis, Kappa angle.

questions.text: Most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults is
questions.solution: Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and accounts for 80% of all uveal melanomas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Electroretinogram (ERG) is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa (RP).

ERG is a sensitive diagnostic test in retinitis pigmentosa that shows reduced scotopic, subnormal responses in early disease and becomes completely extinguished in advanced disease. Electroocoulogram (EOG) is also abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophy affecting the rods more than the cones. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness and delayed adaptation which gradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision.

The classic triad of findings in RP comprises:

  1. Bone-spicule retinal pigmentation
  2. Arteriolar attenuation
  3. ‘Waxy’ disc pallor

The image below shows the classical triad findings of retinitis pigmentosa.

Systemic associations of RP include:

  • Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome -retinitis pigmentosa, obesity, hypogenitalism,polydactyly and mental deficiency
  • Cockayne's syndrome-retinitis pigmentosa,infantile deafness, dwarfism, mental retardation and ataxia
  • Refsum's syndrome-retinitis pigmemosa, peripheral neuropathy and cerebellar ataxia
  • Usher's syndrome
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome

The Argus II Retinal prosthesis also called the "artificial retina" has been approved to treat adults with severe to profound retinitis pigmentosa. The device is designed to replicate the function of photoreceptors in converting visual information into electrical neural signals. There are no other satisfactory treatment for retinitis pigmentosa.

questions.text: Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat in an isolated optic neuritis patient is called______
questions.solution:
Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat in an isolated optic neuritis patient is called Uhthoff’s phenomenon.

Uhthoff’s symptoms

  • Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat.
  • Usually, occurs while having a bath.
  • Vision deteriorates on having a bath with hot water.

Pulfrich’s phenomenon (Option b)

  • Depth perception, particularly for the moving object may be impaired.
  • Both are seen in Multiple sclerosis.

Option c:

Riddoch phenomenon

  • Ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets
  • Seen in cortical blindness

questions.text: The structure involved in Tolosa-Hunt syndrome is :
questions.solution:
All the above mentioned structures are involved in Tolosa–Hunt syndrome.

Tolosa–Hunt syndrome refers to idiopathic nonspecific granulomatous inflammation involving the superior orbital fissure, and/or orbital apex and/or cavernous sinus.

Clinically, it manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and depending upon the extent of involvement may present as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome.

Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by:

  • Pain, typically labeled as retro–orbital ache
  • Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of ophthalmic division of 5th cranial nerve.
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerve involvement
  • Ptosis due to 3rd nerve paralysis.

Orbital apex syndrome includes:

  • Features of superior orbital fissure syndrome described above
  • Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e. early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: All of the following muscles originate from apex of orbit except
questions.solution:
Inferior oblique is the only extraocular muscle not arising from the apex of the orbit.

Inferior oblique:

  • Origin: Anteriorly from the lower and inner orbital walls near the lacrimal fossa – orbital surface of maxilla.
  • It then passes below the inferior rectus (i.e. the inferior rectus lies between the globe and inferior oblique muscle)
  • Insertion: Sclera below and lateral to the posterior pole of the globe.
  • Nerve supply: Inferior division of occulomotor nerve
  • Function:
    • Primary action – Extortion
    • Secondary action - Elevation (best when eye is in adducted position) and abduction

(Mnemonic: RAD – Recti are adductors; SIN – Superiors are intortors)
